title: My Weird Winter Skin Thing and the Lavender Tallow Balm That Fixed It
body:
Okay so it’s February. Or maybe it’s still January. The days are all the same. The air outside feels like it’s actively trying to suck the moisture out of your face. You know that feeling? It’s not just dry. It’s that tight, itchy, almost crispy feeling. Like your skin is a piece of paper that’s been left on a radiator. My knuckles were starting to look like a dried-up riverbed. My cheeks felt like sandpaper. I was putting on lotion like five times a day and it would just… vanish. Poof. Gone in ten minutes. My skin was drinking it and asking for more. It was exhausting. I was sitting there one night, it was like 11:47pm, scratching my wrist absentmindedly while watching some true crime thing, and I just thought, *this is stupid*. There has to be something that actually sticks around.

I’d tried everything. The thick drugstore creams in the tub. The fancy French pharmacy stuff my friend swore by that cost like fifty bucks for a tiny tube. Oils. Serums. You name it. It was either too greasy and just sat on top, or it absorbed and left me right back where I started. I felt like I was just feeding my skin appetizers. It needed a main course.

Anyway, I kept seeing people talk about tallow. Beef tallow. For your face. I know. It sounds insane. Like, why would I put cooking fat on my skin? My first thought was, absolutely not. It’s gonna smell like a steak and clog my pores and be a huge mess. But I was desperate. And the more I poked around, the more it sort of… made a weird kind of sense. The stuff is basically the fat from grass-fed cows, whipped up into a balm. They make it in France, apparently. The science-y part, which I only half-understand, is that it’s supposed to be really similar to the oils our own skin makes. So instead of just sitting on top, it sinks in and tells your skin it can chill out on the oil production. Or something like that. Good for super dry patches, chapped lips, even stuff like psoriasis. I was skeptical, but my winter skincare routine was a full-blown disaster, so what did I have to lose?

## How Beef Tallow Ended Up on My Nightstand

I ordered a jar of this Whipped Tallow Balm in Lavender from this little Etsy shop. I figured if I was gonna slather cow fat on myself, it should at least smell nice. It arrived in this simple jar. No crazy packaging. I opened it and poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It’s solid but soft, like really dense butter straight from the fridge. You scoop a tiny bit and it melts the second it hits your fingers. It doesn’t feel greasy. It feels… rich. But not heavy? I don’t know how to describe it. It smells like lavender. Not like a fake, air freshener lavender. More like the dried lavender my grandma used to keep in her linen closet. It’s herbal. Calming. Actually really nice.

The first night I used it, I was so nervous. I washed my face, patted it dry, and just rubbed a tiny dab between my palms and pressed it onto my cheeks and forehead. I braced for the grease slick. But it just… sank in. Like, within a minute or two, it was gone. My skin felt soft. Not shiny. Not sticky. Just soft. And it smelled like that herb garden smell. I went to bed thinking, well, at least I’ll smell nice.

Here’s the weird part. I woke up the next morning and my face didn’t feel tight. For the first time in months, I didn’t immediately reach for moisturizer. My skin just felt… normal. Hydrated. Quiet. It wasn’t screaming at me. I kept using it. Just at night. After a week, the dry, flaky patches on my cheeks were just gone. My knuckles stopped cracking. I started putting a little on my lips before bed too. Game changer.

## What This Lavender Tallow Balm Actually Does

Look, I’m not a scientist. I’m just a person whose skin was freaking out. But here’s what I *think* is happening. That whole “mimics human sebum” thing seems legit. It’s like it gives my skin what it’s actually missing, instead of some synthetic thing it doesn’t recognize. So my skin stops panicking and over-producing oil or just shedding everywhere. It’s deeply moisturizing but it doesn’t clog anything. My skin just feels balanced. The lavender scent is a bonus. It’s not overpowering. It’s just this gentle, herbal smell that makes the whole process feel like a little nighttime ritual. It’s relaxing. I put it on, the room smells like lavender, and my brain goes, “okay, sleep time.” It’s become my signal to wind down.

I also used it on this rough patch on my elbow that I’ve had forever. Like, years. Always a little rough and scaly. After a few days of putting the tallow balm on it, it smoothed out. I was shocked. I showed my partner and was like, “look! Feel this!” He was not as impressed as I was, but whatever.

I keep the jar on my nightstand. It’s part of the routine now. Brush teeth, wash face, tallow balm, sleep. It’s simple. I’m not layering seven products anymore. For my dry winter skin, this one thing is doing the work of like, three of my old products. It’s kind of humbling. And a little funny. All that money spent and the thing that works is basically whipped beef fat from France. Life is weird.

## Would I Buy This Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did, actually. I’m about halfway through my first jar and I already got a second one as a backup because I have this irrational fear of running out. I even got one for my mom. She has this psoriasis on her hands that acts up in the cold, and I was like, just try it. She texted me last week saying her hands haven’t looked this good in years. So. There’s that.

If you’re dealing with that awful winter skin feeling—that tight, itchy, cracked desert situation—and nothing seems to help for more than an hour, this might be worth a shot. I was super skeptical. I thought it was a weird hippie trend. But it just… works. It’s not magic. It’s not going to make you look 20 again. But it will make your skin feel calm and hydrated and actually repaired. For a tallow balm in winter, it’s been a total game-changer for me. My skin’s happy, I’m happy, I’m sleeping better because of the lavender smell. That’s more than I can say for any other moisturizer I’ve tried.

Anyway, if your skin is being difficult this season, might be worth a look. I got mine from that Etsy shop, the one with the French-made tallow. It’s just a simple jar of stuff that works.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Weirdly, yes. From what I understand, the fat composition is really close to what our skin already produces. So it absorbs well and doesn’t just sit on top like a greasy mask. It’s like giving your skin something it actually recognizes.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
It hasn’t for me. And I can get clogged pores pretty easy. Because it’s so similar to our own oils, my skin seems to know what to do with it. It sinks in. It doesn’t feel pore-clogging at all. It’s the opposite of that heavy, suffocating feeling.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like real lavender. Not candy or perfume. It’s herbal, a little earthy, and honestly just really calming. It’s not strong. It’s just a nice, gentle scent that fades after a little while. Makes putting it on at night feel like a little treat.
random_tangent: the weather has been weird lately
